Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes and Consequences of Exceptional Diversity in Spiny-Rayed Fishes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Spiny-rayed fishes are one of the most successful radiations of vertebrate animals, with about 17,000 species and astonishing morphological and ecological diversity that includes many culturally and economically important species such as tunas, flounders, seahorses, largemouth bass, and guppies. This diverse group represents one of the last great frontiers to understand vertebrate evolution. In this project, the evolutionary relationships among more than 260 families of these fishes will be studied with several methods of phylogenetic inference using DNA sequence data from 16 protein-coding nuclear genes from specimens of 1,500 species. The phylogenetic trees depicting evolutionary relationships among these groups will be combined with more than 40 fossil calibration points to produce a time-calibrated branching diagram of the evolutionary history of these fishes. This time-calibrated phylogeny and a large anatomical data set of functionally important characteristics of the feeding and locomotor systems from over 1,000 species will then be used to compare the rates of speciation and rates of morphological evolution in lineages that live in the five major habitat types: coral reefs, temperate reefs, near-shore soft bottom, pelagic marine, and freshwater. There is a strong theoretical expectation from previous work that freshwater lineages will show high rates of speciation while coral reefs will show the highest rates of speciation and morphological evolution, but these expectations have never been addressed empirically.

This research will strengthen our understanding of the evolutionary relationships and major evolutionary dynamics of the most poorly understood and yet dauntingly successful radiation of vertebrate animals on the earth today. Over 20,000 new gene sequences and the morphological data set from over 1,000 species will be made available to the scientific community. The project will support the development of three postdoctoral scholars and has a major undergraduate training program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spiny-rayed fishes are a lineage of more than 18,100 species, which is nearly 25% of all living vertebrates. The relationships among the major lineages in this large portion of vertebrate biodiversity remained unresolved, due primarily to cultural traditions in the study of fishes that relied primarily on morphology to make phylogenetic inferences. The award from NSF allowed the collection of an extensive DNA sequence dataset from 10 exon regions from more than 1,000 species of ray-finned fishes, with a particularly focused sampling to include all major lineages of spiny-rayed fishes. The evolutionary trees, or phylogenies, inferred from the DNA sequence data are well resolved and reveal scores of relationships not anticipated by the traditional study of morphology. Our first scientific publications from this work focused on the more inclusive ray-finned fishes, which comprise half of all living vertebrate species. The phylogenetic trees revealed that the Elopomorpha (tarpons, eels, and bonefishes) are the living sister lineage of all teleost fishes, a wholly new perspective on the relationships of early diverging euteleost lineages, and unprecedented resolution among the spiny-rayed fishes. Time-calibrating the phylogeny revealed that the diversification of the major lineages of ray-finned fishes occurred in the late Mesozoic and early Cenozoic, a time we identify as the "Second Age of Fishes."

The phylogenies of the spiny-rayed fishes inferred from the 10 nuclear genes provide the first comprehensive perspective on the evolutionary relationships of this hyper-diverse lineage of vertebrates. The phylogeny not only provides the basis for important changes to the classification of spiny-rayed fishes, but also offers a framework to examine the mechanisms that generated this impressive portion of vertebrate biodiversity. Our analyses identify five lineages that show exceptionally high rates of lineage diversification. These lineages include some of the most species-rich lineages of vertebrates such as gobies, blennies, and cichlids. However, the high rates of lineage diversification detected for two of these lineages, tunas and snailfishes, were entirely unexpected. The new phylogenetic trees for spiny-rayed fishes were deployed to understand the evolutionary history of fish lineages with highly modified pharyngeal jaws, patterns of diversification in the earliest diverging lineage of ray-finned fishes, and the biogeographic history of the important cichlid fishes.

This research program allowed the training and participation in research for five undergraduate students, three graduate students, and three postdoctoral researchers. Outreach efforts included work with volunteers at the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale and two plenary talks at international conferences in Okinawa, Japan and Stockholm, Sweden. These new phylogenies have provided an important basis for ichthyology courses at Yale, University of Tennessee, and University of Kansas.
